com.amplifyframework.core.plugin

Interface Plugin<E>

  • Type Parameters:
    E - The type of escape hatch provided by this plugin
    All Superinterfaces:
    CategoryTypeable
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    AnalyticsPlugin, AndroidLoggingPlugin, ApiPlugin, AuthPlugin, AWSApiPlugin, AWSCognitoAuthPlugin, AWSDataStorePlugin, AWSHubPlugin, AWSPinpointAnalyticsPlugin, AWSPredictionsPlugin, AWSS3StoragePlugin, DataStorePlugin, HubPlugin, JavaLoggingPlugin, LoggingPlugin, PersistentLogStoragePlugin, PredictionsPlugin, StoragePlugin, TensorFlowPredictionsPlugin

    public interface Plugin<E>
extends CategoryTypeable
    A plugin is an implementation of a category's behavior. You can implement custom behavior for an Amplify category by writing a plugin. Plugins are added into the Amplify system before configuration, via calls to Amplify.addPlugin(Plugin). You can remove a plugin from the system with Amplify.removePlugin(Plugin). The lifecycle of a plugin is: 1. configure(JSONObject, Context) is called, loading configuration data in a synchronous way. Do not do "heavy lifting" here, or you may cause ANRs. 2. initialize(Context) is called, providing an opportunity to initialize your plugin using the configuration that was loaded in the previous step. While this method is called synchronously from the Plugin's standpoint, it is executed async, in the background, by the Amplify framework.

    • Method Detail

      • getPluginKey

        java.lang.String getPluginKey()
        Gets a key which uniquely identifies the plugin instance.
        Returns:
        the identifier that identifies the plugin implementation

      • configure

        void configure(org.json.JSONObject pluginConfiguration,
               android.content.Context context)
        throws AmplifyException
        Configure the plugin with customized configuration object. A plugin may or may not require plugin configuration, so see the documentation for details. This hook provides a good opportunity to instantiate resources. Any long-lived initialization should take place in initialize(Context), instead.
        Parameters:
        pluginConfiguration - plugin-specific configuration data
        context - An Android Context
        Throws:
        AmplifyException - an error is encountered during configuration.

      • initialize

        void initialize(android.content.Context context)
         throws AmplifyException
        Initializes the plugin. Perform any "heavy lifting" here.
        Parameters:
        context - An Android Context
        Throws:
        AmplifyException - On initialization failure

      • getEscapeHatch

        E getEscapeHatch()
        Returns escape hatch for plugin to enable lower-level client use-cases.
        Returns:
        the client used by category plugin; null, if there is no escape hatch

      • getVersion

        java.lang.String getVersion()
        Returns the plugin version.
        Returns:
        the plugin version
